must.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to have to do something because it is necessary or important, or because of a law or order
must.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: All passengers must wear seat belts.
It’s getting late. I really must go.
For the engine to work, the green lever must be in the ‘up’ position.
Accidents must be reported to the safety officer.
must.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say someone has to or has got to do something rather than say they must do something, which can sound slightly formal or emphatic:
Everyone has to wear a seat belt.
I‘ve got to go at four o’clock.
Do I have to pay now?
must.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used in negative sentences to say that something should not happen, because of a rule or law or because of the situation
must.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: You mustn’t talk to your mother like that.
This book must not be removed from the library.
We must never forget how much we owe to these brave men.
No one must disturb him while he’s sleeping.
must.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used to say you think something is very likely to be true or very likely to have happened
must.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Sam must be nearly 90 years old now.
His new car must have cost around £20,000.
You must have been really upset.
There must be something wrong with the engine.
Karl must’ve seen ‘Star Wars’ six or seven times.
must.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to suggest that someone should do something, especially because you think they will enjoy it or you think it is a good idea
must.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: You must come and stay with us in London sometime.
‘We must do this again, ’ he said. ‘I’ve enjoyed it thoroughly.’
must.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: used to say that you intend or want to do something
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You say that you must do something
I must get a new key
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: I must to get a new key
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You use must not when saying someone should not do something, for example because it is dangerous or wrong
You must not leave without telling me where you’re going
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: You say that something must have happened, or that someone must have done something, when you are fairly sure that this is true, based on what you know
They must have caught an earlier train
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: You say that you have to do something
She has to do some shopping
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[5]: You use don’t have to when it is not necessary for someone to do something
You don’t have to leave yet
must.translation[0].note_box[0].items[6]: You use had to instead of ‘must’ when talking about the past
He had to get up early the next day
must.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: must do something
used when saying that it is very important that someone does something, because someone in authority or a rule says this, or because of the situation
You must be home by midnight.
He must not smoke in here.
I must remember to call her.
have to do something
to need to do something because it is necessary or important
I have to go home early.
She has to talk to him first.
be obliged to do something
to have to do something, because of a rule or law, or because of the situation you are in
Members of parliament are obliged to declare all their financial interests.
He was obliged to admit defeat.
be required to do something
to have to do something because of a rule or law – used especially in written notices and official documents
New students are required to register with a doctor.
have an obligation to do something
to have to do something because it is the duty of someone in your position to do it, or because you have officially agreed to do it
The landlord is under an obligation to keep the building in good repair.
be forced/compelled to do something
to have to do something that you do not want to do, because you are in a situation that makes it impossible to avoid
She was forced to retire early due to ill health.
must.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: something that you must do or must have
must.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Warm clothes are a must in the mountains.
